theorem succ_add_2 (a b : ℕ) : succ a + b = succ (a + b)  := by

· rw [add_succ, add_succ, hd]

rw [add_succ]

rw [hn]
-- Therefore, we have completed the proof.

rfl

-- Our objective is to prove that for all natural numbers a and b, adding the successor of a to b produces the same result as adding a to the successor of b.
theorem succ_add_logical_deviation_2 (a b : ℕ) : succ a + b = succ (a + b)  := by
-- Begin inductive argument on b, defining the base case where b is 0: succ(a) + 0 is equivalent to succ(a + 0)
induction b with n hn
-- We initiate by validating the base case by employing the equation succ(a+b) = a + succ(b), substituting b with 0 and applying this on the RHS.
rw [← add_succ]
-- Using the identity property of addition for natural numbers, where any number plus zero equals the number itself, we set c equal to succ(a) to obtain succ(a) as the sum of a and succ(0).
rw [add_zero]
-- By applying the formula a + succ(b) = succ(a+b) and setting a to a and b to 0, it results in a + succ(0) = succ(a+0) on the RHS.
rw [add_succ]
-- Let's use the principle that any natural number plus zero is the same natural number, in this case let's say c is equivalent to a, leading us to succ(a) being equal to succ(a) on the RHS.
rw [add_zero]
-- Since we have succ(a) on both sides, we can conclude the base case.
rfl
-- For the induction step, we apply the rule a + succ(b) = succ(a + b) for all a, b in ℕ, substituting a with succ(a) and b with n, thus deriving succ(succ(a) + n) = succ(a+succ(n)).
rw [add_succ]
-- We again apply the identity that a + succ(b) is equivalent to succ(a + b) for all natural numbers a and b. Assigning a as a and b as n leads us to the conclusion that succ(succ(a) + n) is equal to succ(succ(a+n)).
rw [add_succ]
-- Use the induction assumption to rewrite the right side, resulting in succ(succ(a) + n) = succ(succ(a) + n).
rw [← hn]
-- With this, our proof is complete.
rfl

-- We aim to establish that for any given natural numbers a and b, the successor of a when added to b is equal to the successor of the sum of a and b.
theorem succ_add_logical_deviation_2 (a b : ℕ) : succ a + b = succ (a + b)  := by
-- Initiate an induction approach on b, identifying the base case (b=0) as succ(a) + 0 being equal to succ(a + 0)
induction b with n hn
-- We kick off by showing the base case by utilizing the equation succ(a+b) = a + succ(b), replacing b with 0 and incorporating this on the RHS.
rw [← add_succ]
-- We exploit the fact that for all natural numbers c, c plus zero equals c, and in this case, we replace c with succ(a), yielding succ(a) as equivalent to a plus succ(0).
rw [add_zero]
-- Take the relation a + succ(b) = succ(a+b) and substitute a for a and 0 for b to achieve a + succ(0) = succ(a+0) on the RHS.
rw [add_succ]
-- By applying the rule that the sum of any natural number c and zero is c itself, and setting c equal to a, we arrive at succ(a) = succ(a) on the right side of the equation.
rw [add_zero]
-- As succ(a) equals to itself, it's clear that the base case holds true.
rfl
-- In the inductive step, we make use of the equation a + succ(b) = succ(a + b) for every a, b in ℕ, by assigning succ(a) to a and n to b, thereby obtaining succ(succ(a) + n) = succ(a+succ(n)).
rw [add_succ]
-- Again, by using the property that a + succ(b) equals succ(a + b) for all natural numbers a and b and setting a as a and b as n, we are able to express succ(succ(a) + n) as succ(succ(a+n)).
rw [add_succ]
-- By applying the induction hypothesis, we can transform the right side of the equation into succ(succ(a) + n) = succ(succ(a) + n).
rw [← hn]
-- This marks the end of our proof.
rfl

-- The intent is to verify that the sum of the successor of a and b is the same as the successor of the sum of a and b, for all natural numbers a and b.
theorem succ_add_logical_deviation_2 (a b : ℕ) : succ a + b = succ (a + b)  := by
-- Launch the induction procedure on b, setting the base case (b=0) to be succ(a) + 0 corresponding to succ(a + 0)
induction b with n hn
-- We start off by confirming the base case with the aid of the equation succ(a+b) = a + succ(b), replacing b with 0 and inserting this on the RHS.
rw [← add_succ]
-- By substituting c with succ(a) in the identity law of addition, which states that any natural number plus zero is the number itself, we get succ(a) is equal to a plus succ(0).
rw [add_zero]
-- By using the expression a + succ(b) = succ(a+b) and by substituting a for a and 0 for b, we get a + succ(0) = succ(a+0) on the RHS.
rw [add_succ]
-- If we consider the fact that c + 0 equals c for any natural number, and designate c to be a, we have succ(a) equating to succ(a) on the right hand side.
rw [add_zero]
-- Given that succ(a) is identical to succ(a), we have completed the proof for the base case.
rfl
-- To prove the inductive case, we use the equation a + succ(b) = succ(a + b) which holds for all a, b in ℕ, and substitute a with succ(a) and b with n, leading us to the equation succ(succ(a) + n) = succ(a+succ(n)).
rw [add_succ]
-- We once more employ the fact that a + succ(b) is the same as succ(a + b) when a and b are any natural numbers. By substitifying a with a and b with n, we obtain that succ(succ(a) + n) is equivalent to succ(succ(a+n)).
rw [add_succ]
-- Substitute the right-hand side using the inductive hypothesis, which produces succ(succ(a) + n) = succ(succ(a) + n).
rw [← hn]
-- We have thus completed our proof.
rfl

-- Our task is to affirm that for all natural numbers a and b, the equation succ a + b = succ (a + b) holds true.
theorem succ_add_logical_deviation_2 (a b : ℕ) : succ a + b = succ (a + b)  := by
-- Begin the induction on b, establishing the base case (b=0) where succ(a) + 0 matches with succ(a + 0)
induction b with n hn
-- We get going by substantiating the base case using the fact that succ(a+b) = a + succ(b), replacing b with 0 and integrating this on the RHS.
rw [← add_succ]
-- We utilize the principle that the sum of any natural number c and zero is c, and replace c with succ(a), hence obtaining succ(a) as the sum of a and succ(0).
rw [add_zero]
-- Let's use the equation a + succ(b) = succ(a+b) and let a be a and b be 0 in order to get a + succ(0) = succ(a+0) on the right hand side.
rw [add_succ]
-- By utilizing the arithmetic law which states adding zero to any natural number gives the same original number, and attributing c to be a, we end up with succ(a) equating to succ(a) on the RHS.
rw [add_zero]
-- Seeing as succ(a) matches succ(a), we've established the base case.
rfl
-- In proving the inductive step, we deploy the equation a + succ(b) = succ(a + b) for all a, b in the natural numbers, and replace a with succ(a) and b with n, which gives us succ(succ(a) + n) = succ(a+succ(n)).
rw [add_succ]
-- We again leverage the truth that a + succ(b) equates to succ(a + b) for all natural numbers a and b. By letting a be a and b be n, we find that succ(succ(a) + n) corresponds to succ(succ(a+n)).
rw [add_succ]
-- Utilizing the induction hypothesis, we modify the right side of the equation, leading to succ(succ(a) + n) = succ(succ(a) + n).
rw [← hn]
-- This finalizes our proof.
rfl
